user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_strict_:
```c
size_t
MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_strict_ (char *str)
{
#ifdef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  size_t res;
  bool broken;

  res = MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_lenient_ (str, &broken);
  if (broken)
  {
    res = 0;
    str[0] = 0;
  }
  return res;
#else  /* ! MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */
  size_t r;
  size_t w;
  r = 0;
  w = 0;

  while (0 != str[r])
  {
    const char chr = str[r++];
    if ('%' == chr)
    {
      const char d1 = str[r++];
      if (0 == d1)
        return 0;
      else
      {
        const char d2 = str[r++];
        if (0 == d2)
          return 0;
        else
        {
          const int h = toxdigitvalue (d1);
          const int l = toxdigitvalue (d2);
          unsigned char out;
          if ((0 > h) || (0 > l))
            return 0;
          out =
            (unsigned char) (((uint8_t) (((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) h)) << 4))
                             | ((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) l)));
          str[w++] = (char) out;
        }
      }
    }
    else
      str[w++] = chr;
  }
  str[w] = 0;
  return w;
#endif /* ! MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
The primary potential sources of unreachable code are the mutually exclusive conditional-compilation branches controlled by MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE (only one branch will be compiled into a given build) and the nested early returns inside the percent-decoding logic which create multiple return paths. These fragments are provided so they can be inspected in the actual build configuration to ensure no code that remains in the compiled project is actually unreachable.

All other statements in the function are standard control flow: the while loop is guarded by the string-terminator check (while (0 != str[r])) before reading str[r++], the checks for missing percent-encoded digits (d1/d2 == 0) return an error immediately, and the hex-digit validation returns on invalid digits. Those constructs do not by themselves produce unreachable statements in the compiled code and therefore do not require further investigation for Rule 2.1.
